The catalytic diesel particulate filter (CDPF) has consistently been a standard setup for diesel engines. This research introduces and enhances a non-noble metal catalyst, Cs-V, by doping with the rare-earth element La for the CDPF. The impact of La doping on the Cs-V-based soot oxidation catalyst was quantitatively studied using physical and chemical analysis, activity testing, and density functional theory (DFT) techniques. Findings indicated that introducing La into the Cs-V-based non-noble metal catalyst led to an increase in both the surface area and pore volume by 41 % and 18.4 %, respectively. The addition of La enhanced both the clustering and spatial distribution of catalyst particles, positively impacting absorption and catalytic activity. Doping with La significantly increased the chances of oxygen adsorption and dissociation activation in catalytic processes, enhancing the chance of soot-oxidation, lowering the activation energy to 62.1 kJ/mol, and decreasing T10(the temperature at which the conversion rate of soot begins to reach 10 %), T90(the temperature at which the conversion rate of soot reaches 90 %), and, Tm(the peak temperature at which the conversion rate of soot reaches) by 70.2 °C, 66.9 °C, and 69.1 °C respectively in contrast to their un-doped counterparts, while concurrently, La doping led to an average 4.5 % boost in the CDPF regeneration effectiveness. DFT simulation indicated that La doping can weaken the bonding between O atoms, lengthen the bond length between V atoms and solid Oasd within the crystal cell, shorten the bond length between V atoms and solid Oasd with C4 molecules, increase the electronegativity of the configuration Oasd, and make the chemical bonds formed by V*-O* more inclined towards ionic bonds, these changes promote the desorption of -COx groups during soot-oxidation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cs-V based catalysts La doping Soot oxidation Density functional theory Physicochemical properties Abbreviations DPF Diesel Particulate Filter SOF Soluble Organic Fraction THC Total Hydrocarbons PM Particulate Matter PN Particulate Number HC Hydrocarbons DFT Density functional theory BET Brunauer-Emmett-Teller XRD X-ray Diffraction SEM Scanning Electron Microscopy XPS X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy TEM Transmission Electron Microscopy TG Thermogravimetric Analysis TPO Temperature Programmed Oxidation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Diesel engines, known for their superior thermal efficiency, dependability, and longevity, have become the most frequently utilized machinery globally [1]. Currently, diesel engines have achieved an efficiency of 51 % for large sea ships and experimental heavy-duty diesel engines [2]. However, due to the unique combustion process and working principle of diesel engines, the amount of particulate emissions produced is significantly higher than that of gasoline engines, typically ranging from 30 to 80 times that of gasoline engines [3]. Soot particles, a significant contributor to serious health issues such as pneumonia and environmental problems like smog, constitute the primary hazardous emissions from diesel engines [4]. The key requirements for enhancing diesel emission reduction performance involve minimizing both particulate emissions and nitrogen oxide levels [5]. Diesel particle filter (DPF) serves as a proficient method for lowering the amount of particulate emissions [6]. DPF can capture 90 % or even higher particulate matter in diesel engine exhaust with its wall-flow honeycomb ceramic structure [7]. Yet, with the gradual accumulation of soot particles in the DPF porous media carrier, there's a reduction in permeability and a rise in resistance to exhaust gas flow, resulting in heightened engine exhaust back pressure and diminished power and fuel efficiency [8]. Therefore, in order to maintain its long-term efficient working state, it is necessary to promote its effective "regeneration" [9]. By coating the filter wall surface of the DPF carrier channel with a soot oxidation catalyst [10], the activation energy for soot oxidation is reduced, thereby lowering the ignition temperature for particulate matter oxidation, allowing the engine to achieve oxidative combustion of accumulated particles in the DPF at normal exhaust temperatures [11]. The noble metal catalysts represented by Pt and Pd-based catalysts have become widely used as carbon soot oxidation catalysts in current carbon soot particulate filters (CDPF) due to their significant advantages such as excellent high activity and stability [12,13]. J.C.Clerc [14] found that noble metal has high catalytic oxidation efficiency for soluble organic components such as SOF, CO and THC in diesel engine exhaust. The extensive use of diesel engines has accelerated the advancement of catalyst systems and their associated coatings. This development permits the continuous diesel particulate filter technology to function consistently over various thermal conditions and aids in immediate regeneration. Neri G et.al [15] found that even though noble metal catalysts does have high soot catalytic activity, however, they are prone to deactivate at high temperatures and has poor sulfur resistance. What's more, to meet the increasingly stricter vehicle exhaust emission regulation, more catalysts need to be coated on CDPF, which means more noble metal are needed to be applied in diesel soot after-treatment field. Vincenzo Palma et.al [16] found that an increase of catalyst coating amount will decrease the oxidation temperature of soot but will lead to an increase in exhaust back pressure. Zhang et.al [17,18] found that an increase in catalysts coating amount can lead to the emission reduction of CO, HC, PM and PN. When CDPF was installed in the post-treatment system, they found an increase in the proportion of accumulation mode particles and a larger GMD (geometric mean diameter) of particles was also detected. As the catalyst loading increases, the cost issue becomes more prominent [19]. In the context of increasingly scarce precious metal reserves, how to get rid of the dependence on precious metals has become a difficult problem for researchers to overcome. Currently, academics both domestically and internationally concentrate on studying non-precious metal catalysts, including alkali, rare earth elements, and transition metals [20]. Element doping can effectively improve the inherent defects of non-precious metal catalysts, providing strong support for the wide application of non-precious metal catalysts in the field of post-processing [21]. Yi et.al [22] discovered that doping alkali metals with K ions increases oxygen voids in catalyst layers, thereby enhancing the bonding between the catalyst and soot; K-Ce catalysts encourage the burning of soot at cooler temperatures, boosting its particle contacts and oxygen vacancies. Their findings also revealed that Zr's existence augments the redox areas on the catalyst surface. Wang et.al [23] discovered cesium, an alkaline metal, to be a highly effective catalyst for the catalytic oxidation of soot. For increasing catalyst surface imperfections, Cs was identified as an effective option, its inclusion boosts solid-solid-gas interaction effectiveness, and boosts resistance to sulfur. Notably, doping with Cs reduced the catalyst's melting point by 163 °C. Shao et.al [24] found that Cs doping has a significant impact on the soot oxidation performance of perovskite catalysts, which can lower the soot ignition temperature to 350 °C, surface promotion of cesium proves significantly more efficient than bulk promotion for catalyzing soot oxidation on LaCoO3 perovskite catalysts. In addition, transition metal elements like Cu, Fe, and Mn are usually combined with Ce based catalyst to perfect catalysts soot oxidation activity. Cu doping giving a Tm of 427 °C and an exceptionally high CO2 selectivity of nearly 100 % to Ce-based catalysts. Isolated Fe ions, together with corresponding oxygen voids, exhibit efficient catalytic properties in converting NO into N2. Their theory suggests a method for reducing NO using NH3 on Fe-doped ceria, which requires the absorption of O2. The incorporation of CeO2 nanoparticles into Mn2O3 nanosheets exhibits a noteworthy enhancement in catalytic activity, leading to a significant reduction in soot ignition temperature [25–27]. Meng Wang et.al [28] successfully enhanced the activity of nitrogen dioxide in soot oxidation by introducing caesium and cobalt into MnOx catalysts. The efficient utilization of nitrogen dioxide can be attributed to the synergy of cesium, cobalt and manganese, which together promote the production of surface reactive oxygen species, which speed up the reaction process of nitrogen dioxide with soot. Except for Ce based catalysts, V based catalysts also deserve a place in the field of aftertreatment [29]. Johansen et.al [30] found that V based catalyst shows a satisfactory effect in soot removal process, which is well suited as SOx cleaner. Sirivarocha et.al [31] discovered that adding element V to the mix notably elevates the oxidation rate of soot yet diminishes the mechanical robustness of CDPF. Despite V's less potent soot catalytic effect as noble metal catalysts, doping into rare-earth metal oxides can enhance the catalytic efficiency of V-based catalysts. Regarding rare-earth metals, La significantly enhances catalyst efficiency and stability, with the growing ionic radius of rare earth contributing to heightened reducibility and increased oxygen vacancies in these catalysts [32]. Leandro et.al [33] discovered that doping with La enhances soot oxidation in Ce-based catalysts, significantly lowers the soot oxidation temperature, and encourages soot oxidation under 390 °C. Based on extensive literature research, there are currently few research reports on the effect of rare earth element La doping on the oxidation performance of Cs-V-based catalysts for soot oxidation in the current research system of Cs-V-based catalysts. This article systematically investigates the mechanism of action of rare earth element La in the doping transformation of Cs-V-based catalysts through physicochemical property analysis, catalytic activity testing, and DPF regeneration performance testing. It reveals that La doping can significantly reduce the activation energy of soot oxidation and enhance DPF regeneration efficiency. Furthermore, through density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the regulation mechanism of La on V-O bond length, charge density distribution, and desorption process is elucidated at the microscopic level. The research results of this article not only provide important theoretical basis for developing efficient and economical catalytic CDPF, but also have practical application value. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this study, alumina was used as a catalyst carrier. Its high specific surface area and thermal stability enable it to effectively disperse active ingredients. Cs-V-based non-precious metal catalysts were prepared using chemical synthesis methods. By adding La(NO3)3, a La-doped non-precious metal carbon soot oxidizer with 5 % doping concentration was produced, and Fig. 1 displays the detailed process flow chart. (1) Material dissolution Deionized water (50 mL), cesium sulfate (2.0 g), and vanadium sulfate (1.5 g) were added to a blender and mixed to form a uniform solution. In the aforementioned mixing phase, a lanthanum nitrate mixture was incorporated at a 5 % mass ratio into the system to create a lanthanum-infused catalyst. (2) Mixing Combined with alumina, the water-based solution in the crusher was introduced to achieve a suspension via grinding. (3) Powder drying and firing The suspension was then added to a spray dryer, the water present in it was evaporated at a high temperature, thus forming a pre-drying body. The entity, already dried, was transferred to an electric furnace for baking into the end product. (4) Dry Grinding The final powder was placed in a dry powder compactor to refine the powder. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Before coating the catalyst onto the DPF carrier, we characterized the physicochemical properties of the catalyst in powder form. The research examined the physicochemical characteristics of non-precious metal catalysts using diverse catalyst characterization methods. 2.2.1 Specific surface area analysis (BET) The assessment of BET relies on the concept of multi-molecular layer adsorption. This theory determines the adsorption level of an individual molecule under specific partial pressure scenarios and then determines the specimen's particular surface area. In this particular test, N2 was adsorbed and desorbed through isothermal methods at standard temperatures of −195 °C and 200 °C, respectively. Prior to N2 adsorption, the sample requires degassing and vacuum treatment. 2.2.2 Scanning electron microscope (SEM) The imaging mechanism of SEM is distinct from that of conventional optical microscopes, offering superior magnification and resolution. In this research, we employed the Hitachi SU-8220 field emission scanning electron microscope, produced by Hitachi, Ltd. The experiment utilized magnifications of 2 K, 10 K, and 50K. Electron acceleration voltages were fixed at 15 kV, and due to the insulating characteristics of the specimen, it experienced a gold sputtering prior to examination. 2.2.3 X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) Conducting the crystal structure examination of catalysts based on Cs-V, a Bruker D8 VENTURE X-ray powder diffractometer from Germany was employed. This includes a Kα source targeting Cu, operating at a wavelength of λ=0.154 nm; a light tube operating at 2.2 kW; working currents and voltages at 20 mA and 40 kV, respectively; the sample's scanning velocity at 5°/min; and the scanning angle varying from 2θ to 10–80°. 2.2.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) Utilizing XPS is crucial for analyzing the surface and the boundary of catalysts. The testing equipment used in this study is the Escalab Xi+ from Thermo Fischer Corporation in the United States. In this experiment, a single-color Al target Kα source (Mono Al-Kα) was employed, possessing an energy of 1486 eV, a voltage level of 15 kV, a power output of 150 W, a beam area measuring 500 μm, and a vacuum intensity below 8 × 10–9 mbar in the experimental chamber. To ensure detection accuracy, the catalyst sample needs to be cleaned under vacuum conditions before the test. In the testing phase, employing the C 1 s (284.6 eV) peak as a benchmark for energy calibration is crucial to counteract spectral line alterations due to charge influences. 2.2.5 Transmission electron microscopy analysis (TEM) Transmission electron microscopy analysis technology is a microscope technology that uses high-energy electron beams to penetrate ultra-thin samples, providing high-resolution images of the internal structure of the sample. The structures of the catalyst particles were measured using a JEOL-2100F transmission electron microscope (Japan Electronics Co., Ltd.). The catalyst samples were placed in anhydrous ethanol. The suspension was prepared by centrifugation extraction using an ultrasonic shaker for 15 min and dropped onto a support membrane for photography with a magnification of 20,000 times. 2.2.6 In-situ infrared (IR) spectroscopy In-situ infrared spectroscopy analysis technology is a method for monitoring the molecular structure changes of chemical substances in real time during the reaction process. It uses the absorption characteristics of infrared light interacting with substances to identify and quantitatively analyze the chemical components in samples by analyzing the absorption spectrum. In this study, a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer was used to capture the infrared spectra of the catalyst in the range of 400–4000 cm–1, and the structural changes of the functional groups of the catalyst under different reaction temperature conditions were analyzed. DRIFT was used for in-situ infrared spectroscopy analysis, with a ratio of soot to catalyst of 1:1. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements To further investigate the performance of the catalyst, we conducted catalytic activity measurements on the catalyst in powder form. Methodologies for testing catalyst activity in this research include thermogravimetric assessment (TG analysis) and temperature-dependent oxidation (TPO analysis). 2.3.1 Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) In order to understand the change in the catalytic efficiency of target catalyst soot with temperature, this study used the TG 209 F1 Libra® thermogravimetric analyzer from NETZSCH in Germany. Printex-U type soot is used to replace diesel engine exhaust particulate matter, as both have similar chemical composition and specific surface area. Before use, place it in a 100 °C drying oven to dry it to remove adsorbed moisture. Take each group of catalyst and carbon soot particles with a total mass of 6 mg and a mass mixing ratio of 1:1. 2.3.2 O2-TPO temperature programmed oxidation The research incorporated the O2-TPO temperature oxidation test to investigate the catalytic impact of catalyst samples on soot oxidation reactions, augmenting TG thermogravimetry findings. The methodology involved the AutoChem II 2920 chemical adsorption analyzer by Micromeritics, an American firm. For this experiment, a blend of 100 mg of catalyst and a 10:1 dilution of pre-processed synthetic soot was used for two hours and then positioned in a quartz tube. The process involved a steady temperature of introducing 1000 ppm NO, 10 % O2, and N2 (balance gas) for an hour at 500 mL/min flow rate. Subsequently, N2 was introduced, and the temperature increased to 650 °C at 10 °C/min. The infrared gas analysis module continuously monitored the evaporation of NO, NO2, CO, and CO2. The primary emphasis of this research is on the typical temperature and activation energy for catalytic soot oxidation. Key temperatures encompass T10, Tm, and T90. Using the Coats-Redfern method, we computed the chemical reaction's activation energy. Given the comprehensive structure of the Arrhenius equation, it's often presumed that this reaction adheres to first-order kinetic patterns. Employing a linear model on experimental data facilitates the precise computation of both the activation energy and its pre-exponential factor. The essential equation for determining the activation energy is outlined as follows: (1) ln ( g ( α ) T 2 ) = − E R T + l n ( A β ) Where g(α) is the most probable mechanism function, usually taken as -ln(1-α), α is the conversion rate. Where T is the temperature (K), and E is the reaction activation energy (kg/mol). R is the universal gas constant, and β is the heating rate (K/min). 2.4 Regenerative performance testing of catalyzed DPF The DPG (Automated DPF and GPF Testing System) equipment designed and produced by the UK Cambustion company was used to test the soot loading and regeneration performance of Cs-V-based and Cs-V-La based catalyzed DPF. Fig. 2 shows the physical drawing of the equipment and the test console. The test object of DPG is the DPF carrier loaded with a soot oxidation catalyst. The DPF uses a wall-flow cordierite honeycomb ceramic carrier to capture particulate matter through a synergistic effect of physical interception and catalytic oxidation. The specific specifications are shown in Table 1 . It is worth noting that the DPG equipment used in this experiment is a dedicated device for DPF carbon accumulation and regeneration, and the front end of the gas flow channel is not coupled with DOC. First, install the diesel particulate filter (DPF) used for testing on the DPG test equipment, and set up a carbon accumulation program in the control computer of the equipment. In the carbon black regeneration test, the carbon accumulation of the two groups of carriers was set at four levels: 1 g/L, 3 g/L, 5 g/L, and 7 g/L. The regeneration process was conducted at an airspeed of 200 kg/hr, temperatures of 450 °C and 550 °C, for a duration of 10 min. By measuring the weight change of the carrier before and after carbon accumulation and the weight after regeneration, the weight loss rate of carbon black is calculated to determine the active regeneration efficiency of the DPF. It should be noted that before the first carbon accumulation, the DPF carrier needs to be placed in a muffle furnace for high-temperature treatment to remove excess water vapor from the carrier. After each carbon accumulation-regeneration test, it is also necessary to use a muffle furnace to burn off the carbon black that was not fully burned during the regeneration process. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) modeling calculations The structure characteristics of the active component Cs2V4O11 within Cs-V catalysts were determined to be a = 5.671 Å, b = 9.639 Å, and c = 5.222 Å [34]. The crystal cell model based on the crystal parameter for Cs2V4O11 is established in Fig. 3 . The Forcite module was used for molecular dynamics optimization of the model, and the CASTEP module was applied for fine geometric structure optimization. The crystal XRD pattern of Cs2V4O11 based on the simulation calculations is shown in Fig. 4 . Comparing the data from our simulations and experiments, it becomes apparent that the trio of prominent peaks in the diffraction pattern, specifically the intensity of the three low-index crystal planes, correspond closely with the findings from the Cs2V4O11 powder characterization tests. This indicates that the model we formulated is applicable for future performance simulations. Prior to executing simulated studies on the catalytic behavior of the Cs2V4O11 interface, it was crucial to execute surface cutting, form a vacuum layer, and construct a configuration for adsorption. Selecting an appropriate exposure layer was also essential, situated between the cutting surface and the vacuum layer. Through simulation calculations, it was found that the surface energy of the 111–1 exposed surface of Cs2V4O11 was the lowest at 0.127 eV/Å2. For building the carbon smoke absorption mechanism of the catalyst, a wire must be linked between the Cs2V4O11 crystal cell and the Oasd-absorbed soot. Moreover, C4 molecular rings were employed to model the soil, ensuring particles and atoms at the model's foundation remained stable via surface energy examination. In theoretical simulation calculations, the surface energy is calculated based on the assumption that the energy required to cut a block into two surfaces is equivalent to the energy required to cut two surfaces in half. Specifically, it is necessary to establish a vacuum layer (for 3D reconstruction) on the cut surface and optimize the parallel geometric structure to obtain energy values, which are then used in the following formula for surface energy calculation: (2) γ s = 1 2 A [ E s l a b − n E b u l k ] In the formula, γ s represents the magnitude of surface energy, expressed in e V / Å 2 ; E s l a b represents the total energy of the crystal; E b u l k represents the energy of atoms in a single cell; n represents the varied correlation between the quantity of atoms present in the cut surface and those in the unit cell; A represents the area of the cutting surface. Adsorbed molecules form chemical bonds with atoms on the solid surface, leading to chemical changes. If gas molecule A is adsorbed on solid surface B, the calculation method of adsorption energy is as follows: (3) E a d s = E A B − E A − E B In the formula, E a d s represents the adsorption energy; E A B represents the energy of the entire system after gas molecule A is adsorbed on solid surface B; E A represents the energy of gas molecule A; E B represents the energy of solid surface B. The Cs2V4O11 crystal cell, undoped, was linked to C4 molecules via a dual-coordinate V atom and an inoperative Oasd atom. Emphasizing the significance, the doping technique for the rare-earth element La is replicated by replacing elements and modifying their compilation of atoms [35]. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 BET Fig. 5 illustrates the distinct surface area and pore efficiency in both Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalyst specimens. Catalysts made from non-precious metals with Cs-V characteristics boast specific surface areas and pore volumes, measuring 18.79 m2/g and 0.076 cm3/g respectively. By incorporating rare-earth element La into the material, its specific surface area expanded to 26.51 m2/g and its pore volume increased to 0.090 cm3/g. A catalyst with an expanded specific surface area correlates with higher active sites, thus enhancing the absorption and oxidation efficiency of reactive substances on its surface [36]. 3.1.2 SEM Fig. 6 displays SEM photographs of the catalyst samples for Cs-V and Cs-V-La. Fig. 6 also exhibits enlarged photographs of the Cs-V catalyst powder samples at the temperatures of 1, 3, and 5K. The high-magnification structure of the Cs-V catalyst reveals that the grouped blocks consist of closely bonded spherical particles. Within diverse types of catalytic processes, the properties of this specific spatial configuration obstruct the uptake of gas molecules and their interaction with solid particles. As a result, this will negatively impact the catalytic functions. Incorporating La into the catalyst enhances both the dispersal and the spatial clustering dimensions of the catalyst particles. However, Fig. 6(f) shows, that many spherical particles adhere to the larger plate-type structure, which exhibits a coral-like structure. The design of this structure enhances its structural integrity and specific surface area [37]. Hundred catalyst particles were selected using Nano-Measure software for particle size measurement processing. Graphs illustrating the spatial distribution of particles using Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalysts samples can be seen in Fig. 7 . The graph illustrates that post-La doping, the Cs-V-based catalysts, devoid of rare-earth metal doping, concentrate their particles near 25 nm, while post-La doping, these catalysts exhibit a more condensed particle size around 20 nm. Research shows that doping with La reduces the size of particles in Cs-V-based catalysts and enhances their dispersal. 3.1.3 XRD Fig. 8 displays the XRD patterns for both Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalysts. Al2O3 is used as a catalyst carrier. The Cs2V4O11 crystals possess a cubic structure of fluorite, aiding in the accumulation and release of oxygen [38]. There was no significant change in the diffraction peak type after doping the catalyst with La, however, the diffraction peak position and half-peak width of the main peak showed change. The doping element La partially replaces V atoms and therefore the main peak of the XRD diffraction shifts significantly to the right, that is, towards a higher-angle direction. According to the Bragg formula, an angle's increment equates to a reduction in the interplanar gap 'd' and the cellular parameters. Hence, the reduction in crystal cell characteristics could be ascribed to the creation of solid solutions between the doped La element and Cs2V4O11, owing to interactions in solid solutions. Fig. 9 illustrates the measured particle sizes of Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalysts, computed through the Scherrer equation. Post La doping, there was a notable decrease in the particle size from 18.1 nm to 6.9 nm. The calculated particle size is consistent with the results of the observed specific surface area by SEM analysis. 3.1.4 XPS Fig. 10 display the XPS spectra of the Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalysts. By integrating the peak areas of each atom, the relative concentrations of C, O, V, Cs, and La atoms on the surface of the carrier were calculated, as shown in Table 2 . In the samples, the elements C, V, and O each exist in a singular, valent state, having valences of +1, +5, and −2, in that order. The charged La element exhibits a valence level of +3. Observing the diagram reveals that, even though the V ion consistently retains a + 5 valence, a minor alteration in the peak's position occurs when La is integrated. This alteration might be explained by the way the infused La and V interact with electrons outside the nucleus, which reinforces the integration of La into the Cs2V4O11 structure. The spectral profile of O1 s shows three separate peaks, located at 530.4 eV, 531.2 eV, and 532.1 eV, in that order. These notable peaks represent lattice oxygen levels, oxygen at areas of defect, and oxygen absorbed or separated by chemicals. The trio of oxygen types typically present on the exterior of catalysts with oxygen and are found as interconversion from OV through OL to OC. The peak area of OC in all four samples revealed a greater OC concentration in Cs-V-La compared to Cs-V. This suggests that La-doped Cs-V-based catalysts, unlike their undoped counterparts, are superior in enhancing oxygen's adsorption and dissociation properties, thus boosting its catalytic efficiency. The BET outcomes for these Cs-V-based catalysts lead to the deduction that the efficiency of soot catalysts is primarily influenced by the OC content, which surpasses the weight of the catalytic surface area. The preceding data leads to the inference that increased OC levels correlate with enhanced efficiency of the soot catalyst. 3.1.5 TEM Fig. 11 presents the EDS spectral data for both Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalysts. Analysis of the elemental spectrum reveals a consistent distribution of La within the Cs-V-La catalyst. Following La addition, V tends to clump more, possibly due to the electron interaction between Doped La and V outside the nucleus. This also corresponds to the conclusion inferred from XPS experiments: La is embedded inside the Cs2V4O11 lattice, and a solid solution is formed between the doped La element and Cs2V4O11 through solid-solution interaction, leading to a reduction in the cellular parameters. Concurrently, following the doping with La, C, and O, scattering occurred, aligning with XPS analysis findings that the OC levels in Cs-V-La surpassed those in Cs-V. Catseninated with La, a Cs-V type, are found to boost oxygen's adsorption and dissociation capabilities more effectively than their un-doped counterparts, enhancing catalytic performance. 3.1.6 FT-IR Fig. 12 illustrates the FT-IR spectral analysis of both Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalysts. Investigating catalytic burning through in-situ infrared spectroscopy showed that the 2360 cm-1 spectral peak matches the enone group, a byproduct of soot burning. The observed peaks at 1595 cm-1 and 1357 cm-1 are due to chelated bidentate carbonates, while the 1068 cm-1 peak signifies bonded bidentate carbonates. These surface carbonates mainly originate from CO2 adsorbed on Cs-V-based catalysts, indicating that Cs-V-based catalysts are involved in soot combustion [39]. 3.2 Catalyst activity performance Depicted in Fig. 13 are the performance curves in thermogravimetry for both Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalysts. Clearly, there is a decrease in the weight of soot particles with increasing temperatures. Catalyst depletion primarily unfolds in a dual-stage process: During the initial heating stage, when the temperature rises from 0 °C to 500 °C, the catalyst gradually loses weight due to evaporation of the internal water vapor, but not more than 5 %. As temperatures increase further from 500 °C to 800 °C, the catalyst markedly enhances the oxidized performance of the soot particles. An upward temperature shift results in a pronounced decline in the sample's mass fraction curve. The results show that compared with high temperature weight loss, the catalyst with lanthanum-doped Cs-V has more obvious weight loss and lower mass curve at low temperature. The findings demonstrate that doping with La enhances catalytic oxidation at reduced temperatures, speeding up the combustion of soot and speeding up the reaction speed. In Fig. 14 , the TPO curves of Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalysts are illustrated, highlighting the scenario when the catalyst is loosely connected to soot. The spectrum of temperature at which soot oxidizes on the catalysts varies between 200 and 450 °C. At elevated temperatures, soot oxidation combustion achieves a conversion rate surpassing 90 %, nearing 100 %. Throughout the process of soot oxidation, we identified the unique temperatures and chemical properties of four catalyst clusters. The chosen standard temperatures include those where the soot combustion rate hits 10 % (T10), the highest soot conversion rate point (Tm), and the temperature where it attains 90 % (T90). The activation energy of the chemical reactions was calculated based on the Coats-Redfern method [40]. Fig 15 illustrates the activation energy for Cs-V and Cs-V-La catalysts. Observations show that Cs-V-based carbon soot catalysts, when infused with La, exhibit reduced characteristic temperatures and diminished energy necessary for chemical reactions. The chemical activation energy Ea of La doped catalysts decreased to 62.1 kJ/mol, and their T10 and T90 (279.5 °C and 380.6 °C) decreased by 70.2 °C and 66.9 °C respectively compared to the undoped Cs-V group. At the same time, the soot conversion rate reached its peak earlier. Conversely, the intrinsic characteristics of the rare earth element La also modify the primary catalyst: integrating La elevates its lattice oxygen levels, which, upon activation at elevated temperatures, lead to the formation of active oxygen types with potent oxidizing capabilities, consequently boosting the oxidation efficiency of soot [41]. It's readily noticeable that the outcomes from the temperature-regulated oxidation examination of catalyst soot align with those from the thermogravimetric examination, suggesting La doping enhances the oxidation efficacy of Cs-V-based non-precious metal catalysts. 3.3 Catalyzed DPF regeneration performance Fig. 16 shows the regeneration efficiency of Cs-V and Cs-V-La CDPF of different soot loading after a ten minutes regeneration process of 550 °C, air velocity of 220 kg/h. It is not difficult to find that as the carbon accumulation increases, the regeneration efficiency of CDPF also decreases. Clearly, the integration of La element into the Cs-V-based CDPF resulted in a mean enhancement of 4.5 % in its regeneration efficiency across diverse soot loadings. 3.4 DFT calculations 3.4.1 Adsorption energy Fig. 17 depicts the energy required for adsorption and the distance between two coordinating V atoms in Cs2V4O11 and an O2 molecule, signifying the commencement of the catalytic process. Clearly, the strongest interaction between the O2 molecule and the uninfused Cs2V4O11 is observed. When La is infused, the bond strength between the catalyst and the O2 molecule reduces. The figure also shows that the arrangement infused with rare earth elements creates a more intense force on the oxygen (OO) bond among O2 atoms. In the adsorbed configuration of the Cs-V-La O2 molecule, the OO bond measures 1.472 Å, with longer bonds between molecules becoming more susceptible to breaking [42]. This suggests that while La element doping decreases the absorption energy for O2 molecules, it enhances their impact on chemical bonds, thus reducing the separation of O atoms and encouraging the formation of active Oasd atoms. Fig. 18 depicts the energy involved in adsorption and the length of adsorption bonds for Cs-V-OC4. The enhanced adsorption energy for C4 molecules on a La-doped Cs-V catalyst layer is evident, suggesting a steadier state of adsorption. In contrast to the single-threaded adsorption structure of Cs-V-O2 that captures O2 molecules, in this setup, Oasd's attachment to the C4 molecule occurs in a single-threaded manner, eliminating the need for desorption post-absorption and maximizing the adsorption energy. One can readily notice that the chemical bonds among Oasd, C1, and V atoms display different levels of reverse stretching following La doping. The replacement of metal V atoms on Cs2V4O11's surface with La enhances the oxidation process of the simulated soot C4 molecule, leading to a notable improvement. The increased count of outer electrons in La atoms might explain this, aiding in the movement of valence electrons and boosting the efficiency of bond breaking throughout the reaction. 3.4.2 Charge density difference Fig. 19 displays the disparity in charge density among Cs, V-O, and C4. Within the diagram, areas colored blue symbolize electron gain, whereas those shaded in yellow denote electron loss. Each atom is encircled by irregular 3D spherical surfaces, each composed of points where the electron gain and loss properties are the same. Before the C4 molecule was adsorbed, the absence of a chemical link between the C1 atom and Oasd suggests a convergence of electron clouds. Following the attachment of the C4 molecule to Cs-V-O, chemical linkages formed, creating blue for electron gain and yellow for electron loss through atomic electron transfer. The charge density differential diagrams between the two C4 molecule adsorption configurations predominantly show that most electrons come from Oasd, with the C1 atom shedding electrons, and those in the O*-C1 bonding area experiencing both gain and loss. Oasd's electrons predominantly emerge from the C1 atom situated on the flank of the C4 molecule. For an enhanced examination and juxtaposition of the charge density variance in the two smoke adsorption setup groups, this research assessed both the charge density variation and Δρ. The findings can be viewed in Fig. 20 . Electron acquisition and depletion at the O*-C1 binding location are highly noticeable. The group fluctuations in the La doping are very significant. After adsorbing the C4 molecules, the electron migration of the system increased and the reaction was active. Among them, the group doped with La exhibited an electron number of 18.9e. 4 Conclusions The research utilized catalyst examination, analysis of catalyst activity, and density functional theory to explore the impact of infrequent element La on the physicochemistry and oxidation efficiency of Cs-V non-metallic soot catalysts. The conclusions are as follows: The addition of rare earth element La enhances the concentration and spatial distribution morphology of catalyst surface particles. The BET surface area of Cs-V non-precious metal catalyst increased by 41 % and pore volume increased by 18.4 %. In XRD diffraction analysis, after doping La, the main peak shifted at a wider angle, the half-peak width increased, the lattice parameter decreased and the catalyst particle size decreased. The increase in the chemical adsorption or dissociation of the oxygen OC concentration of O in the catalyst helps to enhance the process of soot-oxidation. (1) La doping also helps to enhance the likelihood of oxygen uptake and triggering of dissociation in catalytic processes, thereby enhancing the reaction probability of soot-oxidation, reducing activation energy to 62.1 kJ/mol and making T10, T90, and Tm reduced by 70.2 °C, 66.9 °C, and 69.1 °C, respectively compared to un-doped catalysts, and an average improvement of 4.5 % was obtained in the CDPF regeneration efficiency by using La doping. (2) DFT simulation indicated that La doping can weaken the bonding between O atoms, lengthen the bond length between V atoms and solid Oasd within the crystal cell, shorten the bond length between V atoms and solid Oasd with C4 molecules, increase the electronegativity of the configuration Oasd, make the chemical bonds formed by V*-O* more inclined towards ionic bonds, the changes mentioned above promote the desorption of -COx groups during soot-oxidation. The Cs-V based nonprecious metal catalyst synthesized in this study exhibited good catalytic activity in soot oxidation. Notably, adding lanthanum to diesel particulate filters can significantly improve particle capture efficiency and the oxidation regeneration capabilities. However, further investigation is required to assess the durability and reliability of catalysts under operational conditions, which will be the focus of future research. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic diesel particulate filter (CDPF) has consistently been a standard setup for diesel engines. This research introduces and enhances a non-noble metal catalyst, Cs-V, by doping with the rare-earth element La for the CDPF. The impact of La doping on the Cs-V-based soot oxidation catalyst was quantitatively studied using physical and chemical analysis, activity testing, and density functional theory (DFT) techniques. Findings indicated that introducing La into the Cs-V-based non-noble metal catalyst led to an increase in both the surface area and pore volume by 41 % and 18.4 %, respectively. The addition of La enhanced both the clustering and spatial distribution of catalyst particles, positively impacting absorption and catalytic activity. Doping with La significantly increased the chances of oxygen adsorption and dissociation activation in catalytic processes, enhancing the chance of soot-oxidation, lowering the activation energy to 62.1 kJ/mol, and decreasing T10(the temperature at which the conversion rate of soot begins to reach 10 %), T90(the temperature at which the conversion rate of soot reaches 90 %), and, Tm(the peak temperature at which the conversion rate of soot reaches) by 70.2 °C, 66.9 °C, and 69.1 °C respectively in contrast to their un-doped counterparts, while concurrently, La doping led to an average 4.5 % boost in the CDPF regeneration effectiveness. DFT simulation indicated that La doping can weaken the bonding between O atoms, lengthen the bond length between V atoms and solid Oasd within the crystal cell, shorten the bond length between V atoms and solid Oasd with C4 molecules, increase the electronegativity of the configuration Oasd, and make the chemical bonds formed by V*-O* more inclined towards ionic bonds, these changes promote the desorption of -COx groups during soot-oxidation.
